steps.title: You’ll get better sleep after being out in the sun.
steps.content: You’ll get better sleep after being out in the sun. When it’s dark, your body makes more melatonin, which helps you fall asleep. To feel more alert during the day, go outside to walk, exercise, or just relax while the sun’s out. Since you spent time outside, you’ll produce more melatonin at night and sleep better once you go to bed. [1] X Trustworthy Source HelpGuide Nonprofit organization dedicated to providing free, evidence-based mental health and wellness resources. Go to source If you can’t get outside, open the shades and let in as much natural light as possible. You can also buy a light therapy box online to simulate natural sunlight.

steps.title: You’ll need to sleep later in the morning to get a full night’s rest.
steps.content: You’ll need to sleep later in the morning to get a full night’s rest. If you follow a consistent sleep schedule, try pushing the time you normally go to bed a little later. Since your body is used to getting a certain number of hours of sleep, it will adjust and be easier to sleep in. [2] X Research source Your body adapts better if you make changes to your sleep schedule gradually. If you change it by more than 2 hours a night, it could be harder to get used to.

steps.title: These disrupt your sleep cycle so you’re more likely to wake up early.
steps.content: These disrupt your sleep cycle so you’re more likely to wake up early. Stop drinking any caffeinated drinks or alcohol in the evening a few hours before you plan on sleeping. Since they’re stimulants, they might keep you awake or make you have trouble getting a full night of sleep. [3] X Research source Be careful of hidden sources of caffeine, such as chocolate. [4] X Expert Source Alex Dimitriu, MD Sleep Specialist Expert Interview. 15 October 2020.

steps.title: Blue light from devices interferes with your sleep cycle.
steps.content: Blue light from devices interferes with your sleep cycle. Take a break from electronics at least 1 hour before you try falling asleep. Try to limit using your phone or watching TV in your bedroom since you’re more likely to stay awake and get a bad night of sleep. [5] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source As an alternative, try turning on Night Shift (iOS), Night Light (Windows 10), or use an app like F.lux to reduce the blue light from your device's screen. [6] X Expert Source Alex Dimitriu, MD Sleep Specialist Expert Interview. 15 October 2020.

steps.title: The heat from a shower helps you relax and get better sleep.
steps.content: The heat from a shower helps you relax and get better sleep. About 1–2 hours before you go to bed, hop in the shower and turn it to a hot, comfortable temperature. Stay in the water for about 10 minutes before turning your shower off. [7] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source If you want something more relaxing, then sit in the tub instead. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Boost your body’s melatonin levels to help improve your sleep cycle.
steps.content: Boost your body’s melatonin levels to help improve your sleep cycle. Your body naturally makes melatonin during the day, but a supplement can help out if you have trouble staying asleep. Aim to take 1–3 mg of melatonin about 1 hour before you lie down so you feel sleepy when it’s time for bed. [9] X Research source If you still feel drowsy the next day when you wake up, you may have had too large of a dose. Try a lower dose next time.

steps.title: Block out any light so it doesn’t wake you up in the morning.
steps.content: Block out any light so it doesn’t wake you up in the morning. If you have windows in your room, get curtains that completely block the light so your room stays dark. When you go to bed, turn off all light sources in your room so your room stays completely dark. [10] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source If you can’t make your room dark enough, wear an eye mask to sleep to block out the light.

steps.title: You’ll get the best sleep if you’re not too hot or too cold.
steps.content: You’ll get the best sleep if you’re not too hot or too cold. Your room should be at a temperature where you can lie comfortably under the covers without getting too hot or sweating. [11] X Expert Source Alex Dimitriu, MD Sleep Specialist Expert Interview. 15 October 2020. Set your thermostat to around 65 °F (18 °C), or run an air conditioner or fan while you sleep so you stay cool. [12] X Research source You may need to raise or lower the temperature if your body is more sensitive to heat.

steps.title: Don’t let a text or phone call wake you up throughout the night.
steps.content: Don’t let a text or phone call wake you up throughout the night. Turn the volume down on your phone and shut off any alarms you’ve set. Keep your phone away from your bed so you aren’t tempted to use it. [13] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source Don’t stay up too late chatting with your friends. You can always check any missed calls or texts when you wake up.

steps.title: Try these if your room isn’t quiet or you're a light sleeper.
steps.content: Try these if your room isn’t quiet or you're a light sleeper. You sleep a lot better when there’s peace and quiet, wear earplugs while you’re sleeping. That way, other people outside or in your home moving around early in the morning won’t disturb your sleep. [14] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Release tension in your body so you can drift back off to sleep.
steps.content: Release tension in your body so you can drift back off to sleep. If you’ve woken up, close your eyes and slowly focus on the muscles in your body. Start with your face and slowly relax your muscles as you take deep breaths. Work your way down your body to help you sink into your bed and get some more rest. [15] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source Try tensing your muscles slightly before releasing all the tension for even deeper relaxation.

steps.title: Pick some slow, quiet tunes to use as lullabies.
steps.content: Pick some slow, quiet tunes to use as lullabies. Look for slow instrumental music to play in the background. Avoid anything with a lot of vocals or with a fast beat since those could wake you up even more. Just close your eyes and just focus on the music so you can relax again. [16] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source You can also use a white noise machine to help you fall asleep again.

steps.title: Checking the clock only makes you more stressed about the time.
steps.content: Checking the clock only makes you more stressed about the time. If you’ve woken up too early, keep your eyes closed and avoid checking how long you’ve been awake. Turn your clock away from you or face the other side of the room so you aren’t tempted to check it again. [17] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Lying in bed when you’re not tired can affect how you sleep later on.
steps.content: Lying in bed when you’re not tired can affect how you sleep later on. Even though you want to sleep in, forcing yourself to stay in bed while you’re awake can actually make it harder for you to fall asleep. Get up and leave your bedroom to do something else, like read a book, until you feel tired again. [18] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source
